text: improve your writing sentence types
structure
why is this important
when you understand the different
sentence types you can create variety in
your writing your readers will find your
texts more interesting and easier to
read
the first type is a simple sentence it
has one complete idea it has a subject
and a verb because this complete idea
can stand by itself we call it an
independent clause let's look at two
examples
Jennifer is a teacher subject-verb I
learn from online videos subject-verb
the second type is a compound sentence
it has two or more independent clauses
that are joined by a coordinating
conjunction
the most common coordinating
conjunctions are and but or so in a
compound sentence then we have
independent clauses complete ideas that
could stand alone as two simple
sentences instead we join them together
with a conjunction the conjunction and
expresses addition but a contrast or
alternatives so a result let's look at
some examples here's the first Jennifer
is a teacher but she doesn't work at a
school you see we have two independent
clauses we join them together with our
coordinating conjunction the practice is
to use a comma before the conjunction
now sometimes especially in informal
writing you'll see writers use but at
the beginning of a sentence it's not a
practice that's generally recommended
but it is acceptable if not overused
let's look at another example Jennifer
is a teacher and she works online you
see we have two independent clauses we
join them together with comma and
conjunction I will note that the comma
before and and the comma before or are
not consistently used I see more
consistency with a comma before but and
so but I recommend that we use comma
conjunction to form a compound sentence
let's look at one more example Jennifer
is a teacher and she works online so she
depends on the internet in this compound
sentence how many independent clauses do
you see hopefully you see three Jennifer
is a teacher she works online she
depends on the internet and we have two
coordinating conjunctions to join these
clauses together
the third type is a complex sentence
which has one and only one independent
clause and one or more dependent clauses
dependent clauses have a subordinating
conjunction if we start looking at
examples you'll understand better here's
our first if you post a question I will
answer it I will answer it is the
independent clause it has a subject and
verb it's a complete idea that can stand
alone if you post a question is a
dependent clause it has a subject and
verb but this idea cannot stand alone it
depends on the main Clause for meaning
the general practice is to use a comma
to separate the clauses when the
dependent clause appears first here's a
second example you should pay attention
to punctuation when you write where's
our independent clause here you should
pay attention to punctuation when you
write is the dependent clause when is a
subordinating conjunction all of this
depends on our main Clause
the fourth and last type is a complex
compound sentence it has at least one
dependent clause in two independent
clauses and I'd like to share a tip
remember that very long sentences can be
difficult to read a long sentence can
usually be broken into two so although
you can use complex compound sentences I
don't suggest using a lot of them within
one text here's an example
it is good to review lessons and that is
easy to do when you use an online
resource like this one do you see the
independent clauses there must be two or
more here are at the two independent
clauses our dependent clause is at the
end a comma and coordinating conjunction
join our independent clauses a
subordinating conjunction appears in the
dependent clause I'd like to show you
one more example let's look at a complex
compound sentence with an adjective
clause here we go
people who learn to write clearly become
strong communicators and that is a good
thing to be when you are applying for a
job take a look and find two dependent
clauses these clauses have a subject and
verb but they're not ideas that can
stand alone
here they are who learned to write
clearly when you are applying for a job
the first is an adjective clause
the second is an adverb clause but
they're both dependent on the rest of
the sentence
take a good look at the punctuation used
as well
let's use a quiz to review and make sure
you can identify the four sentence types
number one learning a language can be
fun what kind of sentence is this it's a
simple sentence with one independent
clause to progress happens when you
study regularly what kind of sentence is
this this is a complex sentence we have
one independent clause and one dependent
clause three Jennifers studied Japanese
but she can't remember much of it
what kind of sentence is this this is a
compound sentence we have two
independent clauses and they're joined
by comma conjunction a coordinating
conjunction for Jennifer's studied
Japanese at one point but she can't
remember much of it because it was such
a long time ago what kind of sentence is
this do you know
this is a complex compound sentence we
have two independent clauses and one
dependent clause a coordinating
conjunction joins the independent
clauses and a subordinating conjunction
appears in our dependent clause
